deliberation: Considered whether the prophetic formula 'this word came to Jeremiah from YHWH' personifies 'word' as an agent, but in Biblical Hebrew it functions as a set technical formula for revelation and is read as straightforwardly literal within the canonical worldview. No other imagery or obvious figurative devices appear.

On the surface this is a literal command to construct physical yoke-bars and put them on Jeremiah’s neck. However, in prophetic discourse this constitutes a symbolic action whose very design is metaphorical: the physical yoke represents coming political subjugation. The figurative force lies in the enacted metaphor of wearing a yoke as a symbol of foreign domination, which becomes explicit in later verses.

instances.hebrew_text: עֲשֵׂה לְךָ מוֹסֵרוֹת וּמֹטוֹת וּנְתַתָּם עַל־צַוָּארֶךָ
instances.english_text: Make for yourself thongs and bars of a yoke, and put them on your neck.
vehicle: a yoke placed on the neck
ground: heavy, constraining control imposed from outside
lack of freedom and enforced labor
experiential/affective features of oppression
posture: prophetic sign‑act embodying the necessity of submission
instances.explanation: The physical yoke Jeremiah is commanded to wear functions as an enacted metaphor for the burdensome political control that Babylon will exercise over the nations.

deliberation: This verse narrates the sending of the (already symbolic) yokes to various kings by envoys. The verse itself uses only pronominal reference ('send them') without introducing new imagery; it describes the logistics of the sign‑act rather than employing an additional figurative expression.

The verse is largely formulaic: 'Thus says YHWH of hosts, the God of Israel; Thus you shall say to your masters.' The title 'YHWH of hosts' is a conventional divine epithet and not deployed here as an active image, and 'masters' is literal for suzerain kings. No independent figurative expressions arise in this verse.

This verse combines (1) a list of created entities, including 'the human and the animal,' functioning as a merism for living creatures, and (2) the anthropomorphic phrase 'by my great power and by my outstretched arm,' a conventional metaphor for divine power and effective action. Both are figurative and distinct.

instances.english_text: the humans and the animals that are on the earth
vehicle: humans and animals as two major classes
ground: two complementary categories standing for the whole range
inclusive representation of life forms
use of polar or major groups to imply totality
instances.explanation: The pairing of 'humans and animals' functions as a merism: two representative classes are named in order to signify all living creatures on earth.

instances.english_text: by My great might and My outstretched arm
target: YHWH’s effective power in creation and history
vehicle: human limb extended in forceful action
ground: strength, reach, and capability to act decisively
ability to exert control and accomplish tasks
shared experiential sense of power and effectiveness
instances.explanation: Describing God’s power as an 'outstretched arm' is an anthropomorphic metaphor: divine might is pictured as a strong human arm extended to act forcefully.

deliberation: This verse contains several figurative elements: (1) 'I have given… into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar' where 'hand' metonymically denotes power or control; (2) Nebuchadnezzar called 'My servant'—a metaphor for his role as God’s instrument rather than a literal cultic servant; (3) 'even the wild beasts I have given to him to serve him,' which personifies animals as servants and metaphorically emphasizes the comprehensiveness of his dominion.

instances.hebrew_text: נָתַתִּי אֶת־כׇּל־הָאֲרָצוֹת הָאֵלֶּה בְּיַד נְבוּכַדְנֶאצַּר מֶלֶךְ־בָּבֶל
instances.english_text: I have given all these lands into the hand of King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon
target: Nebuchadnezzar’s divinely granted authority over the lands
vehicle: body part that grasps and wields
ground: association of the hand with power, control, and ability to act
to have something 'in one’s hand' is to have it at one’s disposal
instrumental function of the hand
posture: depicts Nebuchadnezzar as empowered but derivative ruler
instances.explanation: The 'hand' stands metonymically for power and control: giving the lands into Nebuchadnezzar’s hand means granting him authority over them.

instances.english_text: Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, My servant
target: Nebuchadnezzar as an instrument of YHWH’s purposes
foreign imperial ruler functioning as divine agent
vehicle: a servant belonging to a master
social role of a subordinate household worker
ground: relationship of subordination and usefulness to the will of another
carrying out tasks assigned by a superior
dependence and commanded service
posture: reframes the feared king as subordinate to YHWH
assertion of divine sovereignty over empires
instances.explanation: Calling Nebuchadnezzar 'My servant' is metaphorical: he is not God’s worshiping devotee but an agent who, unknowingly, carries out God’s purposes as a servant does a master’s will.

instances.hebrew_text: וְגַם אֶת־חַיַּת הַשָּׂדֶה נָתַתִּי לוֹ לְעׇבְדוֹ
instances.english_text: I even give him the wild beasts to serve him
target: extent of Nebuchadnezzar’s dominion over the natural world in his realm
vehicle: domestic servant imagery applied to animals
ground: complete subjection implied when even animals are pictured as servants
lack of resistance and total control
breadth of authority beyond human subjects
posture: maximizes the perceived scope of his rule under God
instances.explanation: Wild animals are personified as servants, forming a metaphor for the total subjection of the created order within Nebuchadnezzar’s sphere of rule.

deliberation: The main clause about nations serving Nebuchadnezzar and his descendants is standard political language. However, the phrase 'until the time of his own land comes' uses 'time of his land' as a metonymic way of speaking about Babylon’s appointed moment of judgment/overthrow, rather than a literal 'time' belonging to dirt or territory.

instances.english_text: until the turn [lit. time] of his own land comes also
target: the appointed time for Babylon’s downfall and judgment
historical moment of reversal for the empire
vehicle: abstract temporal period linked to territory
ground: lands/states are associated with historical 'times' or seasons
each realm has an allotted period of dominance and of judgment
time metaphorically 'comes' as a visitor or event
posture: relativizes Babylon’s power as limited and time‑bound
theological view of history as divinely scheduled
instances.explanation: The 'time of his land' stands metonymically for the divinely appointed period when Babylon itself will be judged and subjugated by others.

deliberation: This verse contains (1) the central 'yoke' imagery—nations not putting their neck under the yoke of Babylon, clearly metaphorical for political submission; (2) the phrase 'with the sword' as shorthand for military invasion and violent judgment (metonymy); and (3) 'by his hand' for Nebuchadnezzar’s agency, another hand–power metonymy.

instances.hebrew_text: וְאֵת אֲשֶׁר לֹא־יִתֵּן אֶת־צַוָּארוֹ בְּעֹל מֶלֶךְ בָּבֶל
instances.english_text: and that does not put its neck under the yoke of the king of Babylon
target: refusal to submit to Babylonian overlordship
vehicle: a neck that is (or is not) placed under a yoke
draft animal under a heavy harness
ground: yokes signify imposed labor, control, and loss of freedom
placing the neck under a yoke signals acceptance of servitude
resisting the yoke symbolizes refusal of imposed authority
posture: presents submission as the divinely willed path to survival
prophetic framing of foreign domination as a burden to accept
instances.explanation: Political submission to Babylon is depicted as putting one’s neck under a yoke, a metaphor drawn from animals harnessed for labor to express imposed control and loss of autonomy.

instances.hebrew_text: בַּחֶרֶב וּבָרָעָב וּבַדֶּבֶר אֶפְקֹד עַל־הַגּוֹי הַהוּא
instances.english_text: with sword, famine, and pestilence I will visit that nation
target: divine judgment through war and accompanying disasters
vehicle: weapons and plagues listed as agents
ground: the sword represents warfare and killing rather than a single blade
naming instruments to stand for the broader phenomena they cause
triad conveys comprehensive judgment
instances.explanation: Here 'the sword' functions metonymically for warfare and bloodshed (paired with famine and pestilence) as the mode by which God will punish disobedient nations.

instances.english_text: until I have destroyed it by his hand
target: Nebuchadnezzar’s role as executing agent of divine judgment
vehicle: the hand as the means of action
body part that carries out one’s will
ground: the hand is conventionally associated with effective action and power
destroying 'by someone’s hand' means through their agency
instrumental nuance of the hand
posture: presents Nebuchadnezzar as tool in God’s purposes
underscores indirect yet sovereign divine action
instances.explanation: The phrase 'by his hand' uses the hand as a metonymy for Nebuchadnezzar’s agency in carrying out God’s destructive judgment.

deliberation: This verse is an admonition not to listen to various kinds of religious functionaries who advocate resistance to Babylon. The language is straightforwardly referential; no metaphor, personification, or special idiom beyond ordinary titles is introduced.

The verse speaks of false prophecy leading to banishment: 'so that I will drive you out and you shall perish.' The verb 'drive out' can be vivid but here refers literally to exile/expulsion from the land; it is not clearly functioning as a distinct metaphor beyond normal displacement language.

This verse mirrors v.8 but for the compliant nation: 'the nation that brings its neck under the yoke of the king of Babylon and serves him.' The 'neck under the yoke' language again clearly functions as a metaphor for political submission, now presented positively as the path to remaining in one’s land.

instances.hebrew_text: הַגּוֹי אֲשֶׁר יָבִיא אֶת־צַוָּארוֹ בְּעֹל מֶלֶךְ־בָּבֶל
instances.english_text: the nation that puts its neck under the yoke of the king of Babylon
target: willing political submission to Babylonian suzerainty
vehicle: beast of burden harnessed for labor
ground: submitting to a yoke implies acceptance of burdensome control
the neck under a yoke loses freedom of movement
image captures constraint and ongoing obligation
posture: counsels strategic submission as divinely sanctioned
prophetic guidance toward survival through obedience
instances.explanation: Again the yoke metaphor depicts political submission to Babylon as an animal placing its neck under a yoke, emphasizing the heaviness and inevitability of the imposed rule.

deliberation: Jeremiah addresses Zedekiah with the same image: 'Bring your necks under the yoke of the king of Babylon; serve him and his people, and live!' The yoke imagery here directly urges the Judean king to accept vassalage, extending the same metaphor of foreign domination as a yoke on the neck.

instances.english_text: Put your necks under the yoke of the king of Babylon
target: Zedekiah’s and Judah’s political submission to Babylon
ground: yokes represent externally imposed control and hard labor
submitting the neck implies yielding autonomy
figurative alignment of servile labor with vassalage
posture: frames compliance as the way to preserve life
theological acceptance of Babylon as God’s instrument
instances.explanation: The command to put their necks under Babylon’s yoke metaphorically urges the king and people to accept servile subordination to Babylon as an ox submits to a yoke.

deliberation: The verse warns of death 'by sword, famine, and pestilence' if they refuse Babylon’s rule, echoing covenant‑curse formulas. The expression 'by the sword' again uses 'sword' metonymically for warfare and violent killing, while famine and pestilence are literal disasters.

target: forms of divine judgment on resistant nations
vehicle: the 'sword' in a triad with famine and pestilence
ground: the sword is a conventional emblem for war and bloodshed
listing instruments names the causes that bring about death
evokes the full spectrum of covenant curses
posture: serves as a stark warning of comprehensive ruin
instances.explanation: Here 'the sword' functions as a metonym for warfare and violent death, paired with literal famine and disease to depict the severity of the threatened judgment.

deliberation: Repeats the admonition not to listen to false prophets who say 'Do not serve the king of Babylon.' The verbs and nouns are used literally; 'serve' here denotes political subjection but is standard terminology without additional imagery beyond that lexical metaphor of service, which is already embedded in the political vocabulary.

God declares He has not sent the false prophets and that He will drive the people out so that they perish. The language of sending, prophesying, driving out, and perishing describes concrete actions and outcomes; no additional metaphor or special figurative device is clearly foregrounded.

The verse addresses priests and people about claims that Temple vessels will soon return from Babylon. References to 'vessels of the house of YHWH' being returned are literal cultic objects and a literal hoped‑for reversal of exile; no new metaphorical imagery is introduced beyond theological content.

Jeremiah urges, 'Serve the king of Babylon and live! Why should this city become a ruin?' The threat of the city becoming a ruin (חרבה) refers to literal physical destruction. The rhetoric is sharp and includes a rhetorical question, but it does not introduce a distinct metaphor or personification.

The challenge—if they are prophets let them intercede with YHWH of hosts so that the remaining vessels not go to Babylon—uses literal language about intercession and the fate of cult objects. No metaphors, similes, or special idioms (beyond standard religious terms) are present.

This verse lists specific Temple items (columns, the sea, stands, and other vessels) and states that YHWH speaks concerning them. The objects and actions mentioned are literal; no figurative reapplication of these items as symbols occurs in this verse.

Narrates the historical fact that Nebuchadnezzar did not take certain items when he exiled Jeconiah and the nobles. Terms like 'exiled' and the identification of persons and objects are used in their straightforward, historical sense.

Again introduces a divine oracle concerning the vessels remaining in the Temple, palace, and Jerusalem. The reference to these locations and items is literal, preparatory to the prediction in v.22; the verse itself does not contain an explicit figurative expression.

The verse predicts that the vessels will be taken to Babylon and remain there 'until the day I visit/attend to them' (עַד יוֹם פׇּקְדִי אֹתָם). The verb פקד, literally 'to visit/attend,' functions here as an anthropomorphic metaphor for God’s special intervention or gracious attention, an idiom for restoring favor.

instances.english_text: until the day I take note of them [lit. visit them]
target: YHWH’s future act of restoring the exiled vessels
divine intervention to reverse their exile
vehicle: a person visiting or attending to someone/something
ground: visiting implies focused attention and purposeful action on behalf of another
shift from neglect to active concern
restorative engagement signaled by personal 'visitation'
posture: promises eventual divine care and reversal of loss
instances.explanation: Saying that God will 'visit' or 'take note of' the vessels uses an anthropomorphic metaphor for His turning attention to them in order to restore them, not a literal physical visit.
